question.text: Identify the labelings i, ii, and iii in the hemoglobin-oxygen dissociation curve.

options.text:
i. Binding of 1st oxygen molecule (difficult to bind).
ii. Binding of 3rd oxygen molecule (easy to bind).
iii. Binding of 2nd oxygen molecules (very difficult to bind).

i. Binding of 1st oxygen molecule (easy to bind).
ii. Binding of 2nd oxygen molecule (easy to bind).
iii. Binding of 3rd oxygen molecule (very difficult to bind).

i. Binding of 1st oxygen molecule (easy to bind).
ii. Binding of 2nd oxygen molecule (difficul to bind).
iii. Binding of 3rd oxygen molecule (very difficult to bind).

i. Binding of 1st oxygen molecule (difficult to bind).
ii. Binding of 2nd oxygen molecule (easy to bind).
iii. Binding of 3rd oxygen molecule (very difficult to bind).

solution.text: The binding of oxygen and hemoglobin produces a characteristic S-shaped curve relating to pO2 to Hb-O2 saturation. The graph explains the saturation of oxygen with hemoglobin. At rest, approximately 25% of the available O2 is extracted by the tissues, resulting in a venous saturation of 75% and a pO2 of around 5.3 kPa. The P50 is the pO2 at which the Hb-O2 saturation is 50%, normally around 3.5 kPa.
